abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Indoor insecticide applications are the primary tool for reducing malaria transmission in the Solomon Archipelago, a region where <jats:italic>Anopheles farauti</jats:italic> is the only common malaria vector. Due to the evolution of behavioural resistance in some <jats:italic>An</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>farauti</jats:italic> populations, these applications have become less effective. New malaria control interventions are therefore needed in this region, and gene-drives provide a promising new technology. In considering developing a population-specific (local) gene-drive in <jats:italic>An. farauti</jats:italic>, we detail the species’ population genetic structure using microsatellites and whole mitogenomes, finding many spatially confined populations both within and between landmasses. This strong population structure suggests that <jats:italic>An. farauti</jats:italic> would be a useful system for developing a population-specific, confinable gene-drive for field release, where private alleles can be used as <jats:italic>Cas9</jats:italic> targets. Previous work on <jats:italic>Anopheles gambiae</jats:italic> has used the <jats:italic>Cardinal</jats:italic> gene for the development of a global population replacement gene-drive. We therefore also analyse the <jats:italic>Cardinal</jats:italic> gene to assess whether it may be a suitable target to engineer a gene-drive for the modification of local <jats:italic>An. farauti</jats:italic> populations. Despite the extensive population structure observed in <jats:italic>An. farauti</jats:italic> for microsatellites, only one remote island population from Vanuatu contained fixed and private alleles at the <jats:italic>Cardinal</jats:italic> locus. Nonetheless, this study provides an initial framework for further population genomic investigations to discover high-frequency private allele targets in localized <jats:italic>An. farauti</jats:italic> populations. This would enable the development of gene-drive strains for modifying localised populations with minimal chance of escape and may provide a low-risk route to field trial evaluations.</jats:p>
